This project is currently being funded by the ELI Program. You can read more in the My Projects tab, or visit the social media to stay updated!

title: About Me
text:
I grew up in Washington State and moved to the Central Coast in 2022 to attend UCSB, escape the rain, and bask my days in the sun ‚òÄÔ∏è
I‚Äôm passionate about conservation science, marine biology, and climate outreach and education with experience working in research labs + non-profits.
Outside of academics, I‚Äôm interested in learning new recipes, traditional arts, and UI/UX design!

title: Scallion Oil Poached Chicken
text:
‚äπ‚Çä Àö‚ÄßÔ∏µ‚Äø‚Çä‡≠® ·∞î ‡≠ß‚Çä‚ÄøÔ∏µ‚Äß Àö ‚Çä‚äπ
This recipe was adapted from daigasikfaan, who named this her ‚ÄúMarry Me Chicken‚Äù. It uses a Cantonese poaching method that lets the chicken sit in residual heat, resulting in a perfectly soft and tender meat.
‚äπ‚Çä Àö‚ÄßÔ∏µ‚Äø‚Çä‡≠® ·∞î ‡≠ß‚Çä‚ÄøÔ∏µ‚Äß Àö ‚Çä‚äπ

title: FUERTE
text:
The FUERTE program, is a program for undergraduates at UC Santa Barbara. Funded by the U.S. National Science Foundation, FUERTE is is a three-year research program designed to build a foundation to succeed at the university and to develop the skills needed for a career in conservation and environmental sciences, areas that specifically involve fieldwork when doing research.
‚äπ‚Çä Àö‚ÄßÔ∏µ‚Äø‚Çä‡≠® ·∞î ‡≠ß‚Çä‚ÄøÔ∏µ‚Äß Àö ‚Çä‚äπ

title: FUERTE
text:
Summer 1
My first summer began with a summer field trip to the Sierra Nevada Aquatic Research Laboratory (SNARL). I learned about long-term place-based datasets, data collection and analysis. My personal project, working with Sanjana Sujeet and Andrea Estrada, examined plastic collected in the Eastern Sierras.
You can check out our presentation here:
‚äπ‚Çä Àö‚ÄßÔ∏µ‚Äø‚Çä‡≠® ·∞î ‡≠ß‚Çä‚ÄøÔ∏µ‚Äß Àö ‚Çä‚äπ

title: FUERTE
text:
Summer 2
During my second summer, I participated in the DECOMP Lab. I worked with PhD Student, Germ√°n Silva on ‚ÄúResearching Wetland Plant Dynamics and Disturbance Response in a Changing Environment‚Äù, examining how pickleweed plants can be used as environmental indicators.
I participated in on-site field research and sampling at UCSB‚Äôs North Campus Open Space and campus greenhouse.
Helped develop protocol and perform data collection for pickleweed sample prep, anthocyanin extraction, chlorophyll extraction, and soil EC measurements.
‚äπ‚Çä Àö‚ÄßÔ∏µ‚Äø‚Çä‡≠® ·∞î ‡≠ß‚Çä‚ÄøÔ∏µ‚Äß Àö ‚Çä‚äπ

title: FUERTE
text:
Summer 3
This summer, I will be working with CFROG, a Ventura County-based advocacy organization leading a just transition away from fossil fuels to protect our health, economy, and climate.
üôå Stay tuned for updates!
‚äπ‚Çä Àö‚ÄßÔ∏µ‚Äø‚Çä‡≠® ·∞î ‡≠ß‚Çä‚ÄøÔ∏µ‚Äß Àö ‚Çä‚äπ

title: UVSA T·∫øt Festival 2025
text:
This year, I headed the 2025 Marketing Team for the nation‚Äôs largest student-run T·∫øt Festival (Vietnamese Lunar New Year celebration).
‚û°Ô∏èDeveloped and executed marketing campaigns overseeing a marketing budget of $26,000 to target festival audiences, researching outlets, and collecting audience data to enhance sponsorship activations.
‚û°Ô∏èPrepared press releases and managed all promotional information including in-person events, communication with media organizations, creation of promotional flyers, social media management, and through the www.tetfestival.org website.
‚û°Ô∏èManaged and oversaw merchandise set-up, sales, communication, and inventory day-of the festival.
‚äπ‚Çä Àö‚ÄßÔ∏µ‚Äø‚Çä‡≠® ·∞î ‡≠ß‚Çä‚ÄøÔ∏µ‚Äß Àö ‚Çä‚äπ

title: UVSA T·∫øt Festival 2025
text:

title: Tide and Terra Magazine
text:
a UCSB mini magazine focused on communicating environmental topics- by students, from students Tide and Terra is a passion project collaboration between me and my friend, Sanjana Sujeet, that combines both our interests of science communication and environmental issues with art and creative content.
Website coming soon‚Ä¶
This is a draft of our first issue that will be printed in June 2024!

title: EEMB URS Presentation
text: EEMB Undergraduate Research Symposium 2024, Meet the Plastics An Evaluation on Plastics Found in Freshwater Ecosystem Lakes in the Eastern Sierras by Sanjana Sujeet, Evelyn Tsang, & Becca Reynolds

title: About Me
text:
Bookworm

I was a big reader, especially when I was younger. I‚Äôd take my books everywhere I went: On the car, to the restaurants ‚Ä¶ and even when I took baths (sorry Mom and Dad!)

This year, I headed the 2025 Marketing Team for the nation‚Äôs largest student-run T·∫øt Festival (Vietnamese Lunar New Year celebration).
‚û°Ô∏èDeveloped and executed marketing campaigns overseeing a marketing budget of $26,000 to target festival audiences, researching outlets, and collecting audience data to enhance sponsorship activations.
‚û°Ô∏èPrepared press releases and managed all promotional information including in-person events, communication with media organizations, creation of promotional flyers, social media management, and through the www.tetfestival.org website.

title: Scallion Oil Poached Chicken
text:
Ingredients

For the chicken

2-3 drumsticks
3-4 slices of ginger
1 green onion
1/2 tbsp Shaoxing cooking wine



For the oil

3 tbsp vegetable oil
1-2 slices of ginger
1 green onions
1/2 shallot
1 tbsp light soy sauce
1 tbsp oyster sauce
1/2 tsp sugar

title: Scallion Oil Poached Chicken
text:
Steps

In a pot of cold water, add the drumsticks, ginger, green onions, and splash of Shaoxing cooking wine.
Bring the water to a boil, then reduce heat to low, and simmer for another 8 minutes with the lid on. Turn off the heat, keeping the lid covered, and let the chicken sit in residual heat for 15 minutes.







Tip



While the water is boiling, wash and cook your rice.



Dunk the chicken in a bowl of ice water then shred the chicken using your hands and place on your serving plate.







Tip



The ice water helps tighten the skin, giving a smooth texture while locking in moisture.



In a saucepan, add the oil, and turn the heat to low. Add the ginger, green onions, and shallots. Cook until golden brown.







Tip



Cooking the aromatics slowly results in a fragrant and golden oil that brings the dish together!



Turn off the heat and mix the oil with oyster sauce, soy sauce, and sugar. Drizzle this mixture over the chicken and enjoy with rice!

title: Korean Seafood Pancakes (Haemuljeon)
text:
Ingredients
Makes ~5 pancakes

Pancakes

~1/2 cup seafood, chopped
2 green onions, chopped
1 tbsp carrot, chopped
1/4 cup flour
1/4 cup potato starch
1/2 tbsp baking powder
1 egg
1/4 cup water
1/2 tbsp fish sauce
1/2 tbsp chicken boullion powder
1/2 tbsp garlic powder
1/2 tbsp onion powder
salt and pepper to taste
1 tbsp sesame oil
vegetable oil, as needed



Dipping sauce

2 tbsp soy sauce
2 tbsp rice vinegar
1/2 tbsp sesame oil
1/2 green onion, chopped

title: Korean Seafood Pancakes (Haemuljeon)
text:
Steps

Pat dry seafood and vegetables. Prepare and chop to size (I prefer 2in matchsticks)
In a large bowl, whisk together dry ingredients, Then add vegetables and seafood with cold water and mix until combined.
Heat a large skillet over medium heat and add enough vegetable oil to coat evenly
Pour mixture into an even thin (~1/2 in) layer on the skillet.
After about 5 minutes, the bottom of the pancakes will become crunchy ‚Äì gently flip over
Cook another 5 minutes and flip. Repeat until both sides are a light golden brown. Transfer to ctting board Keep making pancakes until the batter is used up!







Tip



Clean the skillet with paper towels between batches



Slice pancakes into wedges and transfer to large serving plate.
In a small bowl, combine depping sauce ingredients and serve with pancake.
